answers.answer: Hi I am 42 and I am 17 weeks pregnant with my 5th child. I wasn't on high risk until I found out I had Gestational Diabetes and High Blood Pressure. Being of a mature age doesn't mean your high risk. I did the screening for Downs and my numbers were good enough not to follow through with amnio. Good luck.

One more thing, is those of mature age may have greater chance of High Blood Pressure and Gestational Diabetes. Just remember there are others out there our age having babies and have a healthy full time bubbas

I am 41 and 18 weeks pregnant. Baby is due Nov 15, a month before I turn 42. So far, this has been a very easy pregnancy. No morning sickness, BP excellent, no trouble with blood sugar.I think as mature moms, part of what causes us to worry is that we are more aware of what CAN go wrong. We have heard that older women are at higher risk for certain things...The fact is, women our age have been having babies for centuries. Both of my grandmothers and at least one of my great grandmothers gave birth in their 40's. One of my grandmother's did so at HOME (great grandma too). All healthy, no complications.Yes, statistically there is a higher probability that we will have an issue...but we also have (hopefully) mature coping skills, solid support systems and a whole lot of wisdom on our side to help us through :)

I had a healthy amazing little boy at 40 (actually, 1 week before 41).With any pregnancy there are risks.  There are always things that can go wrong, but the wonderful thing is they rarely do.  As Christine said so well, women have been doing this a long time, and as you can see from this site, still are.  I think the biggest complication in having babies over 40 is the ability to actually get pregnant (fertility declines over 35). And you got that part just fine!!!  The reality is that yes, we have a slightly elevated risk of miscarriage and chromosomnal abnormalities.  Still, most of the time things are fine.Whether or not to have amnio is a very personal decision.  I personally did choose to and many others choose not to.  No right or wrong here.  A couple of things to ask yourself.Why do you want the info (not a judgemental question, everyone has their own reasons).  I wanted to know in order to be prepared...I don't deal well with surprises.  Others want to know as they would choose to terminate. Again, no judgement and no right or wrong.  It's personal.Another thing to ask yourself is if you are comfortable with the risk associate with it. App. 1 in 400 pregnancies will have complications due to amnio, resulting in a loss of the pregnancy.  Do your research and talk to your Dr.  I was comfortable with the risk, but asked an awful lot of questions beforehand, and made sure I was having it done at a clinic that I felt really good about.Congrats on your pregnancy!  And remember...every single pregnant women worries...just about different things.  Your not alone.

I have become very nervous and anxious, mainly because of my age. I am 7 weeks pregnant. With my othe pregnancies I was calm and relaxed.....Am I placed in a high risk catagory?
